As someone writing something historical and spanning a bunch of Japanese history, this story annoys me a lot more than it used to.
So...PROTIP
Serious historical research will make you autistic about every little detail in a setting.
It's still my headcanon that kitsune and most of the yokai don't act very Shinto-y once they clock out for the day. Nor are they busty, dump-truck booty girls.

But they have fluffy tail(s) to touch.

One of the knocks on digital music from the early CD days was that 44.1k filtered out the highest overtones of some percussion. Add to that how the earliest decks weren't truly decoding 16 bits per sample.

Surprising that I haven't set a story in the late 60s through early 70s as recording tech went from 4-track to 24 in a few years. Anthro recording engineer/producer ftw

Anonymous Tue 03 May 2022 01:13:08 No.47406891 Report

>>47406578
>but that hasn't stopped broad cultural norms from being a thing for areas in real life so I don't see why humans couldn't account for it in a world where anthros are a thing.
Ah see, my ideas and suggestions are for possible classes of culture, not things which *must* exist. Let me put it in a very simple to think of example.

Finnish and Italians.Both can coexist, both can share their ideas, work together, fuck, marry, kill. Diametrically opposed in weather preferences, habits, geography, cuisine, social habits, but still human at the core, with everything it implies. A pure Finnish woman will blush like a fucking tomato if you grab her and do the two cheek kiss thing, a pure Italian man will feel like a turned down man when you force him to just give a handshake. This doesn't *have* to happen, but they are different. Things shipped to one country ain't like things shipped to others, cars aren't made to deal with heavy snow and ice down in Venezia, and they probably don't ship 200 gallons of olive oil an hour over to the Spurdo lands either.

You can account for certain things, but still be left quirking an eyebrow at what people do next door or not be quite catered to. Sure, you could get a Rowenta brand super quiet vaccuum cleaner, but you probably are gonna cheap out on it like everyone else in the planet to the chagrim of the hyper sensitive. You could do anthro specific keyboards with larger keys for bigger guys and girls but that's probably as rare as the big big boots on a shoe store. You could go to a clothes store and find something really nice in design but then you notice the tailhole stuck behind it exposing your lower back. It's not about obligatory conflict, it's about how conflict can arise from differences both physiological, cultural and spiritual, same as they spawn in our own world.

>they come off as if anthros haven't ever interacted with human culture at all even past the surface level,and that tech wouldn't be at all different with having to account for anthros because it just is.
Plenty of humans still find human customs a few miles away odd despite being humans, why wouldn't people who's body's are quite literally optimized to a different way find it odd when they perceive the world differently? It's not about how anthros are homogenous, or humans, but trends still exist and would for either side if we treat them as similar to humans.

An anthro is, for all intents and purposes, a creature that is humanoid like in form, with different bodily specializations compared to humans, with its own culture, habits, diets, climate preferences and personal modulations that can fit within certain environments or societies. An anthro musician would be different from a human due to ear range, an anthro might be less fit for wielding a machinegun for that reason as well, be it alien, co-existing on an evolutionary road, recently mingled or with some kind of isekai thing. I run with this definition as it catches just about everything really.
>>47407113
An African-American, an Italian-American and an Irish-American are not really close at all despite sharing literally everything of humanity. An African-American anthro wouldn't have to follow African-American human culture or customs at all even, but they could. I operate under a basic principle that your perception of the world is altered by your senses, much like the environment has altered culture, certain zones are more warlike, some peaceful, a humanoid who is more specialized in scent and hearing but less on finer motorics would not see the world the same way we do, both figuratively and literally, so I automatically make some division between the two groups. Give a lion the english language but he won't be speaking english as we know it kinda deal.
